revision.text:
{{multiple| {{external links|date=April 2017}} {{refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{US-centric|date=November 2016}} }} '''Science outreach''', also called '''Education and Public Outreach''' ('''EPO''' or '''E/PO''') or simply '''public outreach''',{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} is an [[umbrella term]] for a variety of activities by [[research institute]]s, [[University|universities]], and institutions such as [[science museum]]s, aimed at promoting [[Public awareness of science|public awareness (and understanding) of science]] and making informal contributions to [[science education]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Varner, Johanna|title=Scientific outreach: toward effective public engagement with biological science|journal=BioScience|volume=64|issue=4|year=2014|pages=333–340|doi=10.1093/biosci/biu021}}</ref>
==Scope and history==
While there have always been individual scientists interested in educating the public, science outreach has recently become more organized. For example, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ([[NASA]]) now requires all of its projects to organize suitable outreach activities.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} Also working to inform the public are organizations such as Communicating Astronomy to the Public<ref>[http://www.communicatingastronomy.org/meetings/ Communicating Astronomy to the Public]</ref> and the Washington Declaration on Communicating Astronomy to the Public<ref>[http://www.nrao.edu/ccap/conf_wash.shtml Washington Declaration on Communicating Astronomy to the Public]</ref> that organize conferences for the public on science issues and make efforts to put outreach on a more general institutional footing.
Recently, an increasing number of projects have hired designated outreach scientists (part-time or full-time) that handle public relations for their project. There are also specialized outreach providers such as the Education branch of the [[Space Science Institute]]<ref>[http://www.spacescience.org/education/index.html Education branch of the Space Science Institute]</ref> in Boulder, Colorado and the [[NASA Education and Public Outreach Group at Sonoma State University|Education and Public Outreach Group]] at [[Sonoma State University]] which offer to organize a project's outreach activities on a contractual basis.
In addition to outreach by research institutions, an important part of informal science education are outreach programs such as [[science museum]]s and [[science festival]]s.
==Examples of science outreach activities==
Science outreach can take on a variety of forms.
===Public talks/lectures/discussions=== [[File:Universum für Alle - New book showcases ESO images.jpg|thumb|Universum für Alle: 70 short popular lectures at [[Heidelberg University]].<ref>{{cite news|title=New Book Showcases ESO Images|url=http://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann12091/|accessdate=3 December 2012|newspaper=ESO Announcements}}</ref> ]]
Lectures are probably the oldest form of science outreach, dating back to the 1820s when [[Michael Faraday]] organized the first of the [[Royal Institution|Royal Institution's]] [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures|Christmas Lectures]].<ref>{{cite web | title=The RI Christmas Lectures (Royal Institution Website)| url=http://www.rigb.org/rimain/events/christmaslectures.jsp}}</ref>
Public talks can be part of a lecture series, given at a [[science festival]] or in cooperation with a special interest group such as a local [[astronomy club]]. Public presentations can have a variety of formats, including straightforward lecture formats with or without [[Scientific demonstration|experimental demonstrations]], guided live interviews, and discussions with several participants and a moderator. There are also less formal initiatives such as [[Café Scientifique]], in which a café or bar is the venue for regular meetings involving guest scientists that come to talk about their work or take part in discussions with members of the public.
===Visiting primary and secondary schools===
School students and teachers are an important target group for science outreach. Outreach activities can include scientists visiting schools, giving talks at assemblies, discussions with students, or participation in events such as [[career fair]]s and science and technology camps. One organization that focuses on this kind of science outreach is [[Robogals]]. Many universities also have science outreach programs that are dedicated to building relationships between high school students, university scientists, and K-12 teachers. A few of the most prominent university science outreach programs include Carolina Science Outreach,<ref>{{cite web | title=Carolina Science Outreach | url=http://www.csousc.org}}</ref> the Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science,<ref>{{cite web | title=Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science | url=http://studentorgs.vanderbilt.edu/vsvs/}}</ref> the Rockefeller University Science Outreach Program,<ref>{{cite web | title=Rockefeller University Science Outreach Program | url=http://www.rockefeller.edu/outreach/}}</ref> the Present Your Ph.D. Thesis to a 12-Year Old Outreach Project at University of Texas in Austin,<ref>{{cite web | title=Science Educational Outreach Programs That Benefit Students and Scientists | url=http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002368}}</ref> and the Stanford University Office of Science Outreach.<ref>{{cite web | title=Stanford University Office of Science Outreach| url=http://oso.stanford.edu/}}</ref> Using Canada as an example, it has been estimated that with sufficient organization, every classroom from kindergarten through graduation could in practice receive a visit from one or more scientists annually with participation from only 10-15% of the scientific enterprise.<ref>Bechara J. Saab, [http://www.hypothesisjournal.com/?p=902 "Engaging the Clutch of the Science Communication Continuum – Shifting Science Outreach into High Gear"], ''Hypothesis'' Volume 8 Issue 1 (September 2010).</ref> Some examples of science outreach programs in Canada include: [[Let's Talk Science]], [[Actua (Canadian charity)|Actua]], [[Chemical Institute of Canada|The Chemical Institute of Canada]], and [[Science Rendezvous]].
===Workshops/schools for teachers and/or students=== [[File:Cover of the ALMA radioastronomy manual.jpg|thumb|Cover of the [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array|ALMA]] [[radioastronomy]] manual.<ref>{{cite web|title=ALMA Material for Teachers|url=http://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann15052/|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref>]] Inviting groups of school students to a research institution for a workshop is another popular form of outreach. Formats range from a one-day visit to more involved week-long events such as [[Perimeter Institute]]'s International Summer School for Young Physicists, a two-week-long programs for a total of a hundred Canadian and international students from grade 11.<ref>[http://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/Outreach/Education/ISSYP_Overview International Summer School for Young Physicists]</ref>
Another method of science outreach invites school teachers to participate in workshops where they are able to learn effective strategies to engage students in science. This approach was especially embraced by the [[Canadian Space Agency]] which held an annual "Space Educators" conference up until 2012 to provides teachers with access to resources to educate their students in space-related science.<ref>{{cite web | title=Canadian Space Agency Educators Resources | url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/educators/default.asp}}</ref>
===Supporting science fairs and similar events=== [[File:Cloud chamber as science for general public.jpg|thumb|One of the major goals of [[science festival]]s is to make [[science]] more accessible to [[general public]]. [[Cloud chamber]]s are popular at [[science fair]]s for their ability to visualize otherwise [[invisible]] [[radiation]] that surrounds us.]] Besides organizing independent events, many outreach organizations sponsor existing events that promote sciences awareness. A notable examples are [[science fair]]s, [[public science]] events in which working scientists can participate both as judges and as sponsors of student projects.
=== Online aggregation of science activities, resources, and programs === The internet is a rich source of science activities, resources, and programs. For example, research laboratories often maintain educational outreach projects aimed at translating their science into something meaningful for the general public, often [[K–12|K-12]] students, as an effort to increase research broader impacts required by funding agencies such as the NSF.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/od/oia/special/broaderimpacts/|title=Broader Impacts - National Science Foundation|website=www.nsf.gov|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> These may include activities using fast-growing plants that exhibit distinctive mutants with unique [[phenotype]]s useful to teach K-12 students about both Mendelian and molecular genetics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fpsc.wisc.edu/program/index.shtm|title=FPsc: genetics, evolution, modern genetic sciences|website=fpsc.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> Some institutions and organizations maintain large<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/|title=Home {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> or small<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanfordlab.org/education/updates|title=Education and Outreach {{!}} Sanford Underground Research Facility|website=www.sanfordlab.org|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> aggregations of their activity resources,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanfordlab.org/education/curriculum-modules|title=Curriculum Modules {{!}} Sanford Underground Research Facility|website=www.sanfordlab.org|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> outreach programs,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/outreachprograms.htm|title=Outreach Programs {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> upcoming events calendars,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://today.wisc.edu/events/feed/2/|title=Science / UW-Madison Events Calendar|website=today.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> and partnering programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/sciencealliance.htm|title=Science Alliance {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref>
==Awards==
A number of awards honor commitment to science outreach. Examples include: * Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology, [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]]<ref>[http://www.aaas.org/aboutaaas/awards/public/index.shtml Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology], American Association for the Advancement of Science</ref> * Descartes Prize for Excellence in Science Communication, [[European Commission]]<ref>[http://cordis.europa.eu/science-society/descartes/home.html Descartes Prize for Excellence in Science Communication]</ref> * [[Michael Faraday Prize]] for communicating science to a [[United Kingdom|UK]] audience ([[Royal Society]]) * Communicator award, [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]]<ref>[http://www.dfg.de/en/research_funding/scientific_prizes/communicator_award.html Communicator award], Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft</ref> * Synapse Mentorship Awards, often given for exceptional contributions to science outreach, [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research]]<ref>[http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/32408.html Synapse Mentorship Awards]</ref> * Nicholson Medal for Human Outreach, [[American Physical Society]]<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/awards/nicholson.cfm Nicholson Medal for Human Outreach]</ref> *[[Charles A. Black Award]], for exemplary contributions to public understanding of food and agricultural science * [[Kalinga Prize]] for popularisation of science is an award given by [[UNESCO]] since 1952 for exceptional skill in presenting scientific ideas to lay people
==See also== *[[List of Astronomy Outreach Resources in Europe]] *[[Science museum]] *[[Science festival]] *[[Popular science]] *[[Public science]] *[[Physics Outreach]] *[[Scientific literacy]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://oso.stanford.edu Stanford University Science Outreach Office – links to outreach programs for teachers, students, and the general public] *[http://www.spacescience.org/education/downloads_resources.html Education/Outreach resources] at the [[Space Science Institute]] *[http://www.scientistsineducation.org Scientists in education] *[http://nasascience.nasa.gov/ NASA Science] *[http://www.project2061.org/publications/sfaa Science for All Americans] (from the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]]) *[http://epo.sonoma.edu Sonoma State University E/PO group] *[http://www.capjournal.org Communicating Astronomy with the Public Journal] *[http://www.astronomy2009.org International Year of Astronomy 2009] *[http://www.vanderbilt.edu/cso/index.php Vanderbilt University Center for Science Outreach] *[http://www.letstalkscience.ca Let's Talk Science] *[http://www.STEMout.org STEMout] *[http://www.actua.ca Actua] * [http://www.ibiology.org/ <nowiki>iBiology Free resource for scientists, educators, students and the general public]</nowiki>] * [http://www.senseaboutscience.org Sense About Science]
{{Science and the public |state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Science in society]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Spanish National Research Council |logo = |logo_width = 200px |logo_caption = CSIC's mind Campus |seal = |seal_width = 200px |seal_caption = |image = Edificio central del CSIC (Madrid) 02.jpg |image_size = 280px |image_caption = Headquarters |formed = November 24, 1939 |preceding1 = Junta de Ampliación de Estudios (JAE) |jurisdiction = [[Spain]] |headquarters = Serrano 117. 28006 [[Madrid]] |coordinates = |region_code=ES |employees = 11.112 (2017)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/10/19/ciencia/1508425857_599952.html|title=La plantilla del CSIC se ha reducido un 14% desde que gobierna el PP|last=País|first=El|date=2017-10-19|work=El País|access-date=2018-05-01|language=es|issn=1134-6582}}</ref> |budget = |chief1_name = Rosa María Menéndez López |chief1_position = President |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |website = http://www.csic.es }} The '''Spanish National Research Council'''<ref>Although this is the name officially used as translation in the website of the institution, the actual word-by-word translation would be ''High Council of Scientific Research''</ref> ({{lang-es|Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas}}, '''CSIC''') is the largest public institution dedicated to research in [[Spain]] and the third largest in [[Europe]]. Its main objective is to develop and promote research that will help bring about scientific and technological progress, and it is prepared to collaborate with Spanish and foreign entities in order to achieve this aim.
CSIC plays an important role in scientific and technological policy, since it encompasses an area that takes in everything from basic research to the transfer of knowledge to the productive sector. Its research is driven by its centres and institutes, which are spread across all the autonomous regions. CSIC has 6% of all the staff dedicated to Research and Development in Spain, and they generate approximately 20% of all scientific production in the country.<ref name="Rodrigo Montero, 2009">{{cite web |url=http://www.congreso.es/public_oficiales/L9/CONG/DS/CO/CO_244.PDF#page=4 |title=Comparecencia del Director General del CSIC, ante el Congreso de los Diputados, para informar sobre el funcionamiento y los resultados del CSIC y su aportación a la investigación|website=Congreso.es|accessdate=2017-08-11}}</ref> It also manages a range of important facilities; the most complete and extensive network of specialist libraries, and also has joint research units.
Significant latest research by CSIC is the [[Temperature and Winds for InSight]] (TWINS) module, which is a component of NASA's ''[[InSight]]'' Mars lander, which landed successfully on November 26, 2018. TWINS will monitor weather at the Mars landing site.
==Origins== The CSIC was created in 1939 by the recently victorious [[Francoist]] regime from the assets of the ''Junta para la Ampliación de Estudios'' (JAE) (1907–1939), born within the [[Institución Libre de Enseñanza]] and inspired in the [[Karl Christian Friedrich Krause|Krausist]] philosophy. The initial mandate of the CSIC was to ''restore the classical and Christian unity of the sciences that was destroyed in the 18th century'' ("la restauración de la clásica y cristiana unidad de las ciencias destruida en el siglo XVIII").<ref name="El Pais, 2015"> {{cite web |url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2015/07/24/ciencia/1437736052_945031.html?rel=epr |title=La ciencia que desmanteló Franco|website=Elpais.com|accessdate=2017-08-11}}</ref><ref name="El Pais, 2015b"> {{cite web |url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2014/11/24/ciencia/1416857980_556372.html |title=El CSIC se olvida de su herencia franquista|website=Elpais.com|accessdate=2017-08-11}}</ref> From its 1939 foundation to his 1966 death, its head was [[José María Albareda]], one of the first members of the [[Opus Dei]] and a close friend of its founder, [[Josemaría Escrivá]]. José María Albareda was ordained a priest in 1959, and at his death was succeeded as head of CSIC by Manuel Lora-Tamayo, then the Education minister of [[Francisco Franco|Franco]].
==Duties== According to the Statute’s article 5 of CSIC State Agency,<ref name="BOE 2008">{{cite web |url=http://www.boe.es/aeboe/consultas/bases_datos/doc.php?coleccion=iberlex&id=2008/00591 |title=Real Decreto 1730/2007 de 21 de diciembre por el que se crea la Agencia Estatal Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas y se aprueba su Estatuto|website=Boe.es|accessdate=2017-08-11}}</ref> the current objectives and functions of the CSIC are:
* To carry out scientific and technological research and help to encourage such research, where relevant. * To transfer the results of scientific and technological research to public and private institutions. * To provide scientific-technical services to the General State Administration and public and private institutions. * To boost the creation of technologically based entities and companies. * To help create entities with the ability to oversee the transfer and evaluation of technology. * To train researchers. * To train experts by means of highly specialised courses. * To promote scientific culture in society. * To manage scientific-technical facilities to be used by the scientific research and technological development system. * To participate in international organs and bodies, as requested by the Ministry of Education and Science (the CSIC state agency currently belongs to the Ministry of Science and Innovation). * To participate in national organs and bodies, as requested by the Ministry of Education and Science (the CSIC state agency currently belongs to the Ministry of Science and Innovation). * To participate in designing and implementing the scientific and technological policies of the Ministry of Education and Science (the CSIC state agency currently belongs to the Ministry of Science and Innovation). * To collaborate with other national and international institutions in the promotion and transfer of science and technology, as well as in the creation and development of scientific and technological research centres, institutes and units. * To collaborate with universities in scientific research and technological development activities and in postgraduate education. * To inform, attend and advise public and private entities on science and technology issues. * To train experts in science and technology management. * To collaborate in updating the science and technology knowledge skills of non-university teachers. * To support the execution of the sectorial policies defined by the General State Administration, by preparing technical studies or through applied research activities. * Any other scientific promotion and technological research actions assigned to it by applicable legislation or as commissioned by the Government.
==Scientific-technical areas== Its multidisciplinary and multisectorial nature means CSIC covers all fields of knowledge. Its activity is organised around eight scientific-technical areas:
* Area 1. humanities and social sciences<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/humanidades-y-ciencias-sociales|title=humanidades y ciencias sociales|work=Csic.es}}</ref>in 17 centres * Area 2. biology and [[biomedical science]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/biologia-y-biomedicina|title=biología y biomedicina|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 22 centres * Area 3. natural resources<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/recursos-naturales|title=recursos naturales|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 24 centres * Area 4. [[Agricultural sciences]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/ciencias-agrarias|title=ciencias agrarias|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 23 centres * Area 5. [[Physical Science]] and physical technology<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/ciencia-y-tecnologias-fisicas|title=ciencia y tecnologías físicas|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 24 centres * Area 6. [[Materials science]] and [[food technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/ciencia-y-tecnologia-de-materiales|title=ciencia y tecnología de materiales|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 13 centres * Area 7. [[Food science]] and [[food technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/ciencia-y-tecnologia-de-alimentos|title=ciencia y tecnología de alimentos|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 8 centres * Area 8. [[Chemical science]] and [[chemical technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csic.es/web/guest/ciencia-y-tecnologias-quimicas|title=ciencia y tecnologías químicas|work=Csic.es}}</ref> in 16 centres
==Large facilities== CSIC manages the "Singular Scientific and Technological Infrastructures" (ICTS) which are facilities involving relatively high investment and maintenance costs in relation to R&D investment budgets in their field. The science community and society at large can access them, which is justified by their importance and strategic nature, and for this reason they receive each year many national as well as foreign researchers. These large facilities are recognised and supported by the [[European Union]].
CSIC administers the following 6 Spanish ICTS facilities: * [[Calar Alto Observatory|Calar Alto Astronomical Observatory]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caha.es/|title=Calar Alto Astronomical Observatory|work=Caha.es}}</ref> * [[Doñana National Park|Doñana Reserve]] - Biological Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebd.csic.es/|title=Inicio - Estación Biológica de Doñana|work=Csic.es}}</ref> * [[BIO Hesperides|Hespérides Oceanic Research Vessel]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utm.csic.es/hesperides.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619175434/http://www.utm.csic.es/hesperides.asp |archivedate=2010-06-19 |df= }} </ref> * [[Juan Carlos I Antarctic Base]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utm.csic.es/bae.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415220437/http://www.utm.csic.es/bae.asp |archivedate=2008-04-15 |df= }} </ref> * [[Sarmiento de Gamboa Ocean Research Vessel]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utm.csic.es/sarmiento_his.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918195044/http://www.utm.csic.es/sarmiento_his.asp |archivedate=2010-09-18 |df= }} </ref> * The Integrated Micro and Nanofabrication Clean Room at the [[Microelectronics Institute of Barcelona]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imb-cnm.csic.es/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25&Itemid=70&lang=es|title=IMB-CNM|website=Csic.es}}</ref>
Spain participates in two large European facilities: * [[European Synchrotron Radiation Facility]] * [[Institut Laue–Langevin|Max von Laue-Paul Langevin Institute]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ill.eu/|title=ILL :: Neutrons for science : The world's flagship centre for neutron science|work=Ill.eu}}</ref>

A '''spherically symmetric spacetime''' is a [[spacetime]] whose [[isometry group]] contains a subgroup which is [[Isomorphism|isomorphic]] to the [[rotation group SO(3)]] and the [[Group action#Orbits and stabilizers|orbits]] of this group are 2-spheres (ordinary 2-dimensional [[sphere]]s in 3-dimensional [[Euclidean space]]). The isometries are then interpreted as rotations and a spherically symmetric spacetime is often described as one whose metric is "invariant under rotations". The spacetime metric induces a metric on each orbit 2-sphere (and this induced metric must be a multiple of the metric of a 2-sphere).
Spherical symmetry is a characteristic feature of many solutions of [[Einstein's field equations]] of [[general relativity]], especially the [[Schwarzschild solution]]. A spherically symmetric spacetime can be characterised in another way, namely, by using the notion of [[Killing vector fields]], which, in a very precise sense, [[symmetries in general relativity|preserve the metric]]. The isometries referred to above are actually [[local diffeomorphism|local flow diffeomorphisms]] of Killing vector fields and thus generate these vector fields. For a spherically symmetric spacetime <math>M</math>, there are precisely 3 rotational Killing vector fields. Stated in another way, the dimension of the [[projective vector fields|Killing algebra]] is 3 :<math>\dim K(M) = 3</math>.
It is known (see [[Birkhoff's theorem (relativity)|Birkhoff's theorem]]) that any spherically symmetric solution of the [[vacuum field equations]] is necessarily isometric to a subset of the maximally extended [[Schwarzschild solution]]. This means that the exterior region around a spherically symmetric gravitating object must be [[static spacetime|static]] and [[asymptotically flat]].

* [[Spacetime symmetries]] * [[Deriving the Schwarzschild solution]]

page.title: The Complete Idiot's Guide to Publishing Science Fiction

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Complete Idiot's Guide to Publishing Science Fiction | image = The Complete Idiot's Guide to Publishing Science Fiction.jpg| caption = | author = [[Cory Doctorow]]
[[Karl Schroeder]] | subject = [[Writing]], [[Science fiction]] | publisher = [[Alpha Books]] | pub_date = 2000 | pages = 360 | isbn = 978-0-02-863918-5 | dewey = 808.3/8762 21 | congress = PN3377.5.S3 D63 2000 | oclc = 45076483 }} '''''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Publishing Science Fiction''''' (2001) by [[Cory Doctorow]] and [[Karl Schroeder]] was published as part of ''[[The Complete Idiot's Guide]]'' series of non-fiction manuals released by [[Alpha Books]]. It was the first non-fiction book by Doctorow, a novelist.[http://www.allaboutsymbian.com/features/item/Cory_Doctorow_the_EFF_Interview.php Cory Doctorow (the EFF) Interview] ==Description== Written by a minor proponent of the genre, the purpose of the book is to assist readers to understand the basics of becoming a science fiction author. It describes the various subgenres, writing techniques, and what is entailed with authoring such a piece. Then it describes the publishing business starting with agents, contracts and publishers. ==Reception== ''SFRevu'', in its review, wrote that "the road to publication would be made considerably smoother by the information in this book."[http://www.sfrevu.com/ISSUES/2001/0101/9981%20Idiots%20Guide%20to%20Publishing%20SF/Idiots%20Guide%20to%20Publishing%20SF.htm ''SFRevu''. Review by Ernest Lilley, 2001 (issue 1, vol. 1)] [[Blogcritics]]' Helen Gallagher wrote, "Chapters on long-form journalism, market analysis, and self-publishing round out this truly complete guide.[http://blogcritics.org/book-review-the-complete-idiots-guide6/ Book Review: The Complete Idiot’s Guide to Writing Nonfiction by Christina Boufis | Blogcritics] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kschroeder.com/my-books/idiots-guide-to-sf Co-author Karl Schroeder's book page] {{doctorow-navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Complete Idiot's Guide To Publishing Science Fiction}} [[Category:2001 books]] [[Category:Books about writing]] [[Category:Books by Cory Doctorow]] [[Category:Science fiction books]] {{sf-book-stub}} {{lit-book-stub}}

{{Infobox museum |name = The Tech Museum of Art and Innovation |image = The Tech Museum of Innovation in Downtown San Jose.jpg |caption = The Tech Museum of Innovation from [[Plaza de César Chávez]] in [[Downtown San Jose]]. |pushpin_map=United States San Jose |coordinates = {{Coord|37.3314374|N|121.8907276|W|region:US-CA_type:landmark|display=title}} |established = {{start date and age|1998|10|31}} |location = [[Plaza de César Chávez]],
[[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[California]] |type = [[Science museum|Science]] |visitors = 400,000 annually |president = Tim Ritchie |network = ASTC |architect = [[Ricardo Legorreta]] |website = {{URL|www.thetech.org}} }} '''The Tech Museum of Innovation''', commonly known as '''The Tech''', is a museum of [[science]] and [[technology]] in [[San Jose, California]], in [[Silicon Valley]]. It is located the [[Plaza de César Chávez]] in [[Downtown San Jose]].{{cite web |title = Technology Museums |work = SJLibrary.org |publisher = [[San Jose, California|City of San Jose]] and [[San Jose State University]] |url = http://www.sjlibrary.org/research/web/iguide_subjectList.htm?t=192&catID=680 |accessdate = 2008-12-21 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100613020933/http://sjlibrary.org/research/web/iguide_subjectList.htm?t=192&catID=680 |archivedate = 2010-06-13 |df = }} The Tech is considered one of the premier museums of science and technology in the [[United States]].[https://www.sanjose.org/listings/tech-museum Visit San Jose - The Tech Museum] ==History== [[File:The Tech Museum of Innovation 01718.JPG|thumb|left|The Tech during the ''[[Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D|Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon]]'' exhibit, 2010.]] Planning began in 1978 by members of the Junior League of Palo Alto and later assistance by the San Jose Junior League. The first {{convert|20000|sqft|adj=on}} temporary exhibit finally opened in 1990 "The Garage" as it was named, opened in San Jose's former convention center. On October 31, 1998, it opened a brand-new {{convert|132000|sqft|adj=on}} facility and has had 4,000,000 visitors.{{cite web |title = About Us: The Tech Today |publisher = The Tech Museum of Innovation |url = http://www.thetech.org/about/ |accessdate = 2008-12-21 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220124501/http://www.thetech.org/about/ |archivedate = 2008-12-20 |df = }} The museum is composed of three floors, each with its own significance. The ground floor includes The Tech Store, The Tech Cafe, the IMAX® Dome Theater and a recreational area that is reserved for special events. The Tech's architecture is the work of Mexican architect [[Ricardo Legorreta]].{{cite web|last=Herhold|first=Scott|title=Herhold: Designer of two San Jose museums dies in Mexico|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19660901|publisher=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=13 March 2014}} Four major theme galleries fill the Upper Level and Lower Level of the museum: Communication, Exploration, Innovation and Life Tech. These galleries are constantly being revamped and changed to fit the theme movies and exhibits. On the Lower Level there is also a public piece of artwork titled ''Origin'', which is inside a {{convert|45|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} cylinder.{{cite web|title=Origin|url=http://www.sanjoseculture.org/public_art/collections/Tech%20Museum%20-%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf|publisher=City of San Jose|accessdate=11 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311062627/http://www.sanjoseculture.org/public_art/collections/Tech%20Museum%20-%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf|archivedate=11 March 2014|df=}} The Tech Museum of Innovation reflects its social context, capturing Silicon Valley's celebration of technology with a fascination with what the museum's literature refers to as the "gizmos and gadgets" produced by Valley companies. Early reviews, however, criticized The Tech for failing to provide a coherent direction or message.{{cite journal|last=Perrin|first=Andrew|title=Making Silicon Valley : Culture, Representation, and Technology at the Tech Museum|journal=The Communication Review|year=2002|volume=5|issue=2|page=91|doi=10.1080/10714420212479}} ==Exhibits== [[File:The Tech Museum of Innovation 2 2016-05-14.jpg|thumb|The Tech's [[Google Earth]] exhibit.]] [[File:The Tech Museum of Innovation 3 2016-05-14.jpg|thumb|right|An atrium at The Tech.]] The Tech has many exhibits dealing with energy efficiency, customization, exploration and genetics. The Tech Museum of Innovation offers a new approach to viewing galleries from a wide variety of different media. The majority of these exhibits are interactive and allows the viewer to engage in the learning experience. The Tech also has joint partnerships with local attractions, ranging from jazz festivals to the Global Festival of Art. The [[IMAX]] Dome Theater {{cite news|last=Kaplan|first=Tracey|title=Michael L. Hackworth - Silicon Valley entrepreneur and philanthropist - dies at 71|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_20458100/michael-hackworth-silicon-valley-entrepreneur-and-philanthropist-dies|accessdate=5 March 2014|newspaper=San Jose Mercury News|date=2012-04-25}} shows mainstream movies as well as educational films. It is Northern California's only domed IMAX Theater and can seat up to 280 people.{{cite web|url=https://www.imax.com/theatres/t/hackworth-imax-dome-the-tech-museum/|publisher=IMAX|accessdate=5 March 2014}} ===Social robots=== The Tech has an interactive exhibit where people can design and build robots.{{cite web|last=Deinzer|first=Erin Caslavka|title=Places where you can interact with robots|url=http://www.sfgate.com/travel/fiveplaces/article/Places-where-you-can-interact-with-robots-5295740.php|publisher=SF Gate|accessdate=11 March 2014}} ===The Tech Studio=== The Tech created an open-to-the-public workshop space where the in-house prototypers build new exhibits.{{cite web|last=Chan|first=Norman|title=Exhibit Design at The Tech Museum of Innovation|url=http://www.tested.com/art/makers/460508-exhibit-design-tech-museum-innovation/|publisher=Tested.com|accessdate=2 April 2014}} ===Temporary exhibitions=== On special occasions The Tech will rent out Parkside Hall from the City of San José to host special larger exhibits. In 2007, this hall was the home to the exhibit known as Body Worlds 2, which brought in over 280,000 guests. In winter of 2008, there was a special Leonardo da Vinci exhibit (called Leonardo: 500 Years into the Future) that displayed some of his inventions, findings and pictures. It ended January 25, 2009, after a three-week extension.{{cite web |url=http://www.thetech.org/leonardo/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121122802/http://thetech.org/leonardo/ |archivedate=2009-01-21 |df= }} The Tech formerly hosted [[Star Wars: Where Science Meets Imagination]].{{cite web|last=Alton|first=Elizabeth|title='Star Wars: Where Science Meets Imagination' Makes Its Final Stop |url=http://entertainmentdesigner.com/news/museum-design-news/star-wars-where-science-meets-imagination-makes-its-final-stop-at-the-silicon-valley-tech-museum-of-innovation/|publisher=Entertainment Designer|accessdate=7 February 2014}} The Tech opened a new exhibition on Digital Music in March 2014,{{cite web|last=DDT|first=Rich|title=THE TECH MUSEUM INTERACTIVE DIGITAL MUSIC INSTALLATION - REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS JANUARY 20TH|url=http://rhizome.org/announce/opportunities/60137/view/|publisher=rhizome|accessdate=12 February 2014}} called ''REBOOT:music'', including Tim Thompson's ''Space Palette''.{{cite web|last=Mosher|first=Mark|title=Tim Thompson's Space Palette at The Tech Museum of Innovation REBOOT:Music Exhibit in San Jose|url=http://www.modulatethis.com/2014/04/tim-thompson-space-palette-the-tech-museum-of-innovation-reboot-music-exhibit-san-jose.html|publisher=Modulate this!|accessdate=2 April 2014}} ===The Tech Virtual=== The Tech Virtual launched in December 2007. On June 4, 2008, the world's first museum exhibits developed using this open source method opened in the museum's own Virtual Test Zone gallery. The seven exhibits, all contributed under a Creative Commons license and prototyped in the virtual world of Second Life, became part of the museum's Art, Film, Music and Games exhibition. The Virtual Test Zone gallery itself is a prototype exhibit area that will consistently feature virtual-to-real-world exhibits on specific themes resulting from The Tech Virtual programs. ==Management== The Tech is a registered 501(c)(3) [[nonprofit]].{{cite web|title=The Tech Museum of Innovation|url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=4557|publisher=Charity Navigator}} ===The Tech Awards=== {{main|The Tech Awards}} The Tech Awards is a program of The Tech wherein a yearly ceremony is held for individuals and organizations to get recognition for their technological contributions to improving the human condition. ===The Tech Challenge=== The Tech Challenge is a signature program of The Tech. It is a design challenge competition for students Grades 5–12.{{cite web | title = The Tech Challenge - About Us | publisher = The Tech Museum of Innovation | url = http://thetechchallenge.thetech.org/about-us | accessdate = 2013-03-14 }} Over the past 26 years, The Tech Challenge had around 17,000 students compete by building devices to solve issues such as wildfires, fish removal and landing on an asteroid.{{cite web | title = Cupertino Students Blow Out the Tech Challenge | publisher = Cupertino Patch | url = http://cupertino.patch.com/groups/schools/p/cupertino-students-blow-out-the-tech-challenge | accessdate = 2014-02-06 }} ==See also== {{Commons category}} * [[Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose]] * [[Exploratorium]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.thetech.org/ Museum website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081220124501/http://www.thetech.org/about/ The Tech's About Us web page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080828223833/http://www.thetechvirtual.org/ The Tech Virtual] {{San Jose and Silicon Valley attractions|nocat=yes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tech Museum of Innovation, The}} [[Category:Technology museums in California]] [[Category:Museums in San Jose, California]] [[Category:Children's museums in California]] [[Category:Computer museums in California]] [[Category:Science centers]] [[Category:Science museums in California]] [[Category:IMAX venues]] [[Category:Science and technology in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Silicon Valley]] [[Category:Museums established in 1990]] [[Category:1990 establishments in California]] [[Category:Association of Science-Technology Centers member institutions]] [[Category:Charities based in California]] [[Category:Domes]] [[Category:1990s architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture in California]] [[Category:Ricardo Legorreta buildings]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}}
The role of women in and affiliated with [[NASA]] has varied over time. Their earliest roles were restricted to supportive or administrative jobs, but by the end of the space program there were [[List of female astronauts|women astronauts]]. <!--References format: <ref>Anthony, Fred (2014). [http://catlover.com Chance]. Publisher: Name of Publisher.</ref> -->
==History== Women first worked in support as administrators, computerists, secretaries, doctors, psychologists, and later engineers. In the 1970s NASA started recruiting women and minorities for the space program with little success. Some of the women who worked in these roles included Mary Shep Burton, Gloria B. Martinez, Cathy Osgood, and Shirley Hunt who all worked in the computer division, and Sue Erwin, Lois Ransdell, and Maureen Bowen who worked as secretaries for various members of the Mission and Flight Control teams.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kranz|first1=Gene|title=Failure is Not an Option|date=2000|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|location=NewYork, NY}}</ref> Beginning in 1977 the recruitment slowly began to increase after they had [[Nichelle Nichols]] help with recruitment. Part of the advantage she had in recruitment for the space program was that her role as Lieutenant Uhura on [[Star Trek]] helped inspire girls to attempt to become [[astronaut]]s at NASA when they grew up. One of the girls inspired was [[Mae Jemison]] who was the first Black woman astronaut.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nichols|first1=Nichelle|title=Beyond Uhura|date=1994|publisher=[[G. P. Putnam's Sons]]|location=New York, NY}}</ref> Another important woman was [[Ellen Ochoa]] who joined NASA in 1988 and became the first Hispanic woman to become an astronaut.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Posada-Swaffert|first1=Angela|title=A Place in the Stars; Ellen Ochoa relentlessly pursued her dream|agency=Hispanic|publisher=Hispanic Publishing Corporation|date=June 2003}}</ref>
Some issues NASA faced in recruiting women as well as minorities for the space program was that throughout NASA's history the astronauts had always been white men. This was at least partially caused by the restrictive academic requirements for the earlier astronauts. Originally the astronauts, aside from the specific training from NASA, were required to have master's degrees in various sciences such as engineering so that they could deal with issues that came up during or after the spaceship was launched.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Phelps|first1=J. Alfred|title=They Had A Dream|date=1994|publisher=Presidio Press|location=Novato, CA}}</ref> Another part of the issue was that NASA similar to other businesses, did not look specifically for women to work for them outside of specific areas until the government ratified the Equal Employment Opportunity Act. This discredited NASA with women and minorities when they did try to recruit them as they did not believe NASA actually meant what it said in the recruitment drives. This led to NASA hiring Nichelle Nichols as a recruitment consultant and as the face of their new recruitment drive.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nichols|first1=Nichelle|title=Beyond Uhura|date=1994|publisher=G. P. Putnam's Sons|location=New York, NY}}</ref> After which the recruitment rates for women and minorities increased and eventually led to women astronauts of various ethnic backgrounds.
== Major events == * [[Jerrie Cobb]] appointed NASA administration consultant—1961 * Women join NASA as engineers—1971 * NASA writes plan for recruiting women and minorities for space program—September 12, 1973 * [[Anna Lee Fisher|Anna Fisher]], [[Shannon Lucid|Shannon W. Lucid]], [[Judith Resnik|Judith A. Resnik]], [[Sally Ride|Sally K. Ride]], [[Margaret Rhea Seddon|Margaret R. Seddon]], and [[Kathryn D. Sullivan]] chosen to become astronauts—January 31, 1978 * Sally Ride becomes first woman to fly in space—June 18, 1983 * Astronaut Judith A. Resnik and payload specialist [[Christa McAuliffe|Sharon Christa McAuliffe]] die in [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Challenger accident]]—January 1986<ref>{{cite book|last1=Phelps|first1=J. Alfred|title=They Had A Dream|date=1994|publisher=Presidio Press|location=Novato, CA}}</ref> * Mae Jemison becomes first Black woman in space—September 11, 1992 * Colonel [[Eileen Collins]] becomes first woman to command a spacecraft—July 20, 1999<ref>{{cite news|title=30th Anniversary of Moon Landing Marked at Cape Space|agency=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 17, 1999}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox programming block | name = Xploration Station | image = [[File:Xploration Station Logo.png|200px]] | caption = | premiered = {{Start date|2014|9|13}} | closed = | channel = [[Broadcast syndication|Syndicated]] (primarily [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] stations) | country = [[United States]] | format = [[E/I]] [[Block programming|programming block]] | runtime = 2 hours (2014-2016)
3 hours (2016-present) }} '''Xploration Station''' is an [[United States|American]] [[broadcast syndication|syndicated]] [[Block programming|programming block]] that is programmed by [[Steve Rotfeld Productions]], distributed by [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], and debuted on September 13, 2014. It airs weekends (typically on Saturday mornings), primarily on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]-affiliated stations. Aimed towards teenagers, the block consists of four half-hour shows focusing on the [[STEM fields]] of [[science]], [[technology]], [[engineering]] and [[mathematics]]. All of the programs in the two-hour block are produced to meet federally mandated [[Children's Television Act|educational programming]] guidelines{{cite web|title=Fox Stations Add SRP's Two-Hour STEM Block|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/syndication-and-distribution/fox-stations-add-srps-two-hour-stem-block/128024|author=Paige Albiniak|periodical=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|publisher=[[NewBay Media]]|date=December 17, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2014}} (stations carrying the block continue to provide [[E/I]]-compliant programs acquired from the [[broadcast syndication|syndication]] market to comply with the full three-hour requirement defined by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] for television stations to devote to educational programming each week). ==History== On December 17, 2013, Steve Rotfeld Productions announced that it would launch a two-hour syndicated block of live-action educational programs under the working title ''Xploration Nation'', with [[Fox Television Stations]] and [[Tribune Broadcasting]] initially set to carry the block across their respective Fox owned-and-operated and affiliated stations. The block, aimed towards teenagers between 13 and 16 years of age, features programs focused on the [[STEM fields]] – such as [[marine biology]], [[astronomy]] and [[animal science]].{{cite web|title=Steve Rotfield Clears New Science and Technology Two Hour E/I Block With FOX Station Group|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/12/18/steve-rotfield-clears-new-science-and-technology-two-hour-ei-block-with-fox-station-group/223509/|author=Amanda Kondolojy|website=[[TV by the Numbers]]|publisher=[[Zap2It]] ([[Tribune Digital Ventures]]|date=December 18, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2014}} Production on one of the four shows, ''Xploration Outer Space'', began in April 2014. The block, by then renamed ''Xploration Station'', premiered on September 13, 2014.{{cite news|title=Emily Calandrelli’s new frontier|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/television/2014/09/13/outer-space-scholar-emily-calandrelli-new-frontier/uFPENrdORpthchyYyqYmiJ/story.html|author=Kelly Gifford|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners, LLC|date=September 13, 2014|accessdate=October 3, 2014}} On Fox [[owned-and-operated station]]s, ''Xploration Station'' replaced ''[[Weekend Marketplace]]'', a two-hour block of [[infomercial]]s first introduced in January 2009 following the discontinuation of [[4Kids TV]] due to conflicts between Fox and the block's programmer [[4Licensing Corporation|4Kids Entertainment]].{{cite news|title=Fox Ends Saturday-Morning Cartoons|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/25/business/media/25kidstv.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=November 24, 2008|accessdate=January 11, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403021926/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/25/business/media/25kidstv.html |archivedate=April 3, 2015|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|title=Longform ads replace kid fare on Fox|url=http://www.variety.com/VR1117996360.html|author=Michael Schneider|periodical=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Reed Business Information]]|date=November 23, 2008|accessdate=December 29, 2008}} Several of the Fox stations that initially picked up the block had previously declined to carry the network's former children's programming blocks ([[Fox Kids]], FoxBox and 4Kids TV) and ''Weekend Marketplace'' – particularly, those owned by the core Fox and Tribune groups that [[1994 United States broadcast TV realignment|affiliated with the network in the mid-1990s]] under [[New World Pictures#New World Communications|New World Communications]] ownership. On January 20, 2015, Fox Television Stations renewed the block for the group's Fox owned-and-operated stations through 2017.{{cite news|title=Fox O&Os Renew ‘Xploration Station’|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/82349/fox-oos-renew-xploration-station|website=TVNewsCheck|publisher=NewsCheck Media|date=January 20, 2015|accessdate=January 20, 2015}} One of the more notable holdouts for ''Xploration Station'' in its first two seasons was Fox's largest affiliate group, [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]], which has several already existing contracts with other E/I production companies to give them compliant programming to meet the standards throughout a chain which consists of numerous network affiliates; Sinclair's Fox stations instead continue to carry ''Weekend Marketplace'' (the sole exception is [[WLUK-TV]] in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], which carries ''Xploration Station'' through an agreement struck prior to the December 2014 closure of Sinclair's purchase of the station and [[The CW|CW]]-affiliated sister [[WCWF]] from [[LIN Media]]). This was rectified in September 2016, when Sinclair began to carry ''Xploration Station'' on their Fox stations and two other Sinclair stations associated with a netlet under a five-year agreement with Steve Rotfeld Productions.{{cite news|title=Sinclair to Partner With SRP for 'Xploration Station' Starting Fall 2016|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/syndication-and-distribution/sinclair-partner-srp-xploration-station-starting-fall-2016/138880|author=Paige Albiniak|periodical=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media|date=March 17, 2015|accessdate=March 18, 2015}} The block was made available international with the pick up of non-US distribution by [[Temple Street Productions#Boat Rocker Media|Boat Rocker Rights]] in February 2016.{{cite news|last1=Brzoznowski|first1=Kristin|title=Fox’s Syndicated Science Block Xploration Station to Go Global|url=http://worldscreen.com/tvreal/foxs-syndicated-science-block-xploration-station-to-go-global/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=TV Real|publisher=WSN, Inc.|date=February 24, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Dickens|first1=Andrew|title=Science shows board Boat Rocker|url=http://www.c21media.net/science-shows-board-boat-rocker/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=C21 Media|date=February 25, 2016}} With the third season starting September 10, 2016, Xploration Station expanded from 2 to 3 hours while only returning 3 shows and adding 3 new shows.{{cite press release |last= |first= |date=August 31, 2016 |title=Steve Rotfeld Productions Expands 'Xploration Station' Weekend TV Block to 3 hours for 2016-17 |url=http://www.cbs58.com/story/32938150/steve-rotfeld-productions-expands-xploration-station-weekend-tv-block-to-3-hours-for-2016-17 |location=Philadelphia |publisher=Steve Rotfeld Productions |agency=PRWEB |access-date=September 10, 2016}} In April 2018 Xploration Station won a Daytime Emmy award for its show ''Xploration Earth 2050'' in the category of “Outstanding Special Class Series.”.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/breaking/mc-nws-lower-mac-emmy-20180429-story.html|title=Lower Macungie man wins Emmy for science show|last=Tatu|first=Christina|work=themorningcall.com|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en-US}} ==Programming== ===Current=== *'''''Xploration Awesome Planet''''' (September 13, 2014–present): Hosted by [[Philippe Cousteau, Jr.]], this series features a detailed look at earth science and geology.{{cite web|title=YouTube star Joe Penna boards Fox science show|url=http://realscreen.com/2014/07/30/youtuber-joe-penna-boards-fox-tv-science-show/ |author=Todd Longwell|website=Realscreen|publisher=Brunico Communications|date=July 30, 2014|accessdate=August 13, 2014}} *'''''Xploration DIY Sci''''', also called ''DIY Sci'', (September 10, 2016–present): A pop-science series featuring the host, [[Steve Spangler]], creating experiments using everyday items.{{cite news|title=Extra: Lionsgate inks Anderson, C4 builds "Flat Pack" doc|url=http://realscreen.com/2016/02/12/extra-lionsgate-inks-anderson-c4-builds-flat-pack-doc/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=Realscreen|publisher=Brunico Communications Ltd.|date=February 12, 2016}} *'''''Xploration Earth 2050''''' (September 13, 2014–present): This series covers emerging technology. The first season of the series was hosted by [[Joe Penna]]{{cite web|title=MysteryGuitarMan is the latest YouTube star to get his own TV show|url=http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/joe-penna-xploration-station-mysteryguitarman/|website=[[The Daily Dot]]|accessdate=August 13, 2014}}. The latter seasons were hosted by [[Chuck Pell]]In 2018 The show won a Daytime Emmy Award for “Outstanding Special Class Series.”. The first Emmy win for Xploration Station. *'''''Xploration: Nature Knows Best''''' (September 10, 2016–present): Marine biologist Danni Washington hosts this show about nature based technological advancements.. *'''''Xploration Outer Space''''' (September 13, 2014–present): This series focuses on various aspects of the [[space industry]], including [[space technology|technology]], the prospects of a [[manned mission]] to [[Mars]], and the growing [[space tourism]] industry. The program is hosted and produced by [[Emily Calandrelli]], who was scouted by Steve Rotfeld from her [[YouTube]] productions for [[West Virginia University]]'s engineering college.{{cite web|title=WVU's Calandrelli to Host, Co-Produce TV Show on Fox|url=http://statler.wvu.edu/news/news-details.php?item=1904|work=West Virginia University|date=July 24, 2014|accessdate=July 24, 2014}} *'''''Weird But True''''' (September 10, 2016–present): A co-production of Rotfeld Production and National Geographic Kids and is based on the magazine's most popular fun-facts feature and book series{{cite news|last1=Alessi|first1=Sara|title=Nat Geo Kids’ Weird But True! Lands TV & Radio Shows|url=http://worldscreen.com/tvkids/nat-geo-kids-weird-but-true-lands-tv-radio-shows/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=TV Kids|publisher=World Screen|date=September 9, 2016}} ===Former=== *'''''Xploration Animal Science''''' (formerly ''Animal Science'') (September 13, 2014 – 2016) – This program was originally broadcast in syndication in 2012, and was retooled for broadcast as part of Xploration Station.{{cite web|title=2014-2015 Xploration Animal Science - Season I- Press-Program Information Kit — Extreme Reach Syndication|url=http://syndication.pathfire.com/shows/Xploration%20Station%20Block/Xploration%204%20Animal%20Science/2014-2015%20Season/general-information-and-how-to-find-content/2014-2015%20Xploration%20Animal%20Science%20-%20Season%20I-%20Press-Program%20Information%20Kit.pdf/view|website=Pathfire.com|accessdate=August 8, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Xploration Station - Steve Rotfeld Productions|url=http://www.rotfeldproductions.com/xploration-station/|website=Steve Rotfeld Productions|accessdate=August 8, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907220157/http://www.rotfeldproductions.com/xploration-station/|archivedate=September 7, 2015}} *'''''FabLab''''', became part of the ''Xploration Station'' programming block in early 2016{{cite press release |author= |title=Mayim Bialik And Teen Celebrity Supporters Announce FabLab, The First Science Television Series Aimed At 'Tween And Teen Girls, From The Producers Of The Teen Choice Awards |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mayim-bialik-and-teen-celebrity-supporters-announce-fablab-the-first-science-television-series-aimed-at-tween-and-teen-girls-from-the-producers-of-the-teen-choice-awards-300230598.html |location=LOS ANGELES |publisher= |agency=PRNewswire |date=March 3, 2016 |access-date=2016-03-08}} as an apparent mid-season replacement for ''Animal Science''. The show has 4 hosts, 3 girls as it is focused toward female tween and teens. ==Reception== ''Animal Science'' was nominated in 2014 for a [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Children's Series]].{{cite web|title=Montco TV producers up for daytime Emmys|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/local/20140620_Montco_TV_producers_up_for_daytime_Emmys.html|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=Philadelphia Media Network|date=June 20, 2014|accessdate=August 13, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Daytime Emmy Awards 2014: Complete list of winners and nominees|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/tv/la-et-st-daytime-emmy-awards-2014-complete-list-winners-nominees-story.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Publishing]]|date=May 1, 2014|accessdate=August 13, 2014}} In April 2018 Xploration Station won a Daytime Emmy award for its show Xploration Earth 2050 in the category of “Outstanding Special Class Series.”. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.rotfeldproductions.com/xploration-station/}} {{KidsTVBlocksUS}} [[Category:Television programming blocks in the United States]] [[Category:Science education television series]]
